text: Family Member: If he overdoes it on one day. Doctor: Oh, of course. Oh, everybody does that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Everybody does that not just you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You know there’s two philosophies with that which is like oh, if it’s good day I’m gonna max it out so I can veg out the next day and I have some other patients that will just like pace themselves like I know it’s a good day but I don’t want to pay the price the next day so I’ll just moderate myself and then it’s more even. So, it’s really your preference. Some people would just be like I’d rather have one good day out of three rather than my the eh days. Patient: Right, okay. Doctor: So, a lot of people are different in their activity level. You know, some folks are just go, go, go, and some are like Patient: RIght. Doctor: oh, no, I like to chill and be on my computer and watch my TV and get on the phone, you know, so everyone’s activity level. Patient: I like more activity. Doctor: Yeah.

text: Patient: I'm the lazy investor. Doctor: Yes. Patient: Yeah, the lazy, you know retirement guy. Doctor: Sometimes you can like sign up early for Medicare, because you've got health issues. Those are things we got to get straight before. Yeah. And then Medicare is not all just Medicare, Medicare has dashes attached to Medicare. Some of it is the prescription plan that you need to have. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: So those are things you got to get straight before you do anything else. So we're going to be in deep doo doo. Patient: Okay. Doctor: When it comes to trials, if it's something like, oh, give this new pill to get we give that to you. We don't bill the insurance. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But that Xtandi, we still have to do what we got to do. Obviously, we're gonna support you in any which way we can. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But yeah, before anything drastic happens, and if you sometimes want to just talk to social work about what is the next step, they can guide you there too. Patient: Okay.

text: Family Member: The only difference is Dr G___ was emphatic about having T__ call him after he had visited with you because he would like to know what you had to say. Doctor: Okay, well my sense is you know he and I can talk about sort of when’s the right time to get new pictures, and the lung stuff is interesting because is it just cancer in your lung that causing this gasping, this wheezing? Patient: He doesn’t think so. Doctor: I don’t think so either, but you’d have to rule that out because that can complicate sometimes clinical trials- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: because using experimental therapies in somebody who’s got something else going wrong that’s not the cancer or the therapy- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: when you’re on a trial we can sometimes blame the new drug for that symptom and then that drug gets a black eye. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: So companies want to make sure that you’re good to go on and they’re not going to get a black eye because there’s something going on that’s not related to what they’re doing. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Yes, understand.

text: Patient: Yeah, but if needs be, we can do it, we can do it. There’s another drug that we were on, too, besides Lupron. Doctor: It’s called Zytiga, also known as Abiraterone. Patient: It’s Zytiga. Right. Zytiga. Doctor: And one of the things that you and I have discussed before, and that this might be true especially if you don’t participate in the trial, would be you know could we start the Zytiga without the Lupron. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay, in other words, could we have your oral therapy with the absence of or without the Lupron? Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And as we discussed before, this is generally considered a little bit controversial. It’s not the standard therapy. So if you read a textbook about managing advanced prostate cancer it would only say that you’d give Abiraterone you’d also give an injectable suppression at the same time like Lupron. Patient: Okay. Doctor: However, as I told you before, I have used Abiraterone (Zytiga) Patient: Yes, I have also, and I think I was zero point something for over a year. Doctor: Yeah, about point one.

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Yeah. We definitely have a program to help city residents if they have trouble getting in that often. Huh, huh, you know, the chemotherapy is going to cause hair loss. Huh, seventy-five percent of the time you lose your hair, it grows back. Huh, you might get excess tearing because it can block the tear ducts. So a little bit. The other reason why we might want to wait a little bit is just to see how much your palsy is going to get better. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, huh, it drops blood counts. So right now your white count’s good. Your platelets are good. Huh, but we may need to give you a blood transfusion if we make you more anemic. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, huh, we can drop your blood count, white count, and so you might get a higher risk of infection. Huh, usually we know about that. We tell you to be careful. Sometimes we give you antibiotics. And if it happens every time, sometimes we’re going to give you a medicine that’s going to bring up your white count so it doesn’t drop. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Typically, we don’t use that medicine unless it drops. Huh, over the long haul, you might get, huh, injury to the longest nerves in your body. Those are your fingertips and to your toes. Huh, you get numbness. Huh, so we try to go out as many as ten cycles. Most people notice it by the sixth or seventh. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But I’m going to ask you every time can you zip up your thing? Can you button your pants? Can you button your shirt? If you tell me I can’t, I’m going to stop. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: But if your shirt’s coming in and it’s unbuttoned, even though you tell me you did, I’m not going to believe you. Okay? I have ways to check. Patient: Right. (Laughs)

text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: He was awarded a grant. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So because it was a transformative impact grant, we decided to call the trial the Transformer Trial. So this is a study where we’re testing this high-dose testosterone therapy. Patient: Sure. Doctor: Now there are a few caveats about the trial that you need to be aware of. If your PSA goes above one after we do those scans (we can talk about that in more detail) Patient: Yeah. Doctor: One caveat is, and this is going to seem more paradoxical, is that where patients go in this high-risk testosterone trial, the Transformer Trial, they also have to continue the Lupron. Patient: Lupron. Doctor: Which is a hormone-suppression. Patient: Yeah, yeah, we’ve had that before. Doctor: And that may seem paradoxical to you because on the one hand I’m telling you we’re going to give you testosterone back, and on the other hand I’m telling you we’re going to be giving you Lupron to suppress the testosterone. And it turns out this this is exactly what we want to do. Patient: Uh huh.

text: Patient: I see. Doctor: All the things it does downstream without the ball. We’ve been testing that as part of this trial. So I need to dig into the group that’s testing and find out are you one of those guys that was positive? Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you were positive, that would mean pretty strongly that we shouldn’t try more hormone treatments. You need to be positive for that to go on this immune trial. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh they’re looking for folks who might have more aggressive hormone insensitive cases. So I’m, I’m going to do that this week just to find out. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh so I think that’s a trial. Uh I’m trying to think. I mean, we, we had a, I’m just thinking of one of the study nurses. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: They kept them on the enzalutamide and added this immune drug. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And they had occasional patients who have very dramatic effects. Uh probably about twenty-five percent of the patients they treat. So we have a trial. I’ve got to figure out if we can finesse it because you’re not on enzalutamide any more.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
